caption: Visited with friend and was very lovely, free entry and a ton of things to admire because of the magnitude of the painting. Would highly recommend for a family trip, and there are other sections of the museum to explore although a couple of them are at an added cost.

One of the most delightful museum experiences I’ve unexpectedly had!  The spacious and open halls allow the art to breathe and thrive. The collection is incredibly diverse, ranging from abstract paintings to enigmatic sculptures and even light fixtures! Some pieces are so captivating that they’ve stayed on my mind long after my visit. Surprisingly, the museum wasn’t crowded, making it feel like a hidden gem amidst the city’s numerous museums.  Of course, the best part is that it’s completely free! Please don’t miss out on this gem; add it to your museum list.
I visited the free exhibition and it was pretty nice, you can take your time or go quickly through them, i also liked the museum store, they have a great deal of history and art books.

I visited this free museum in Paris. It has spacious galleries that allow for easy movement and provide ample room to view some impressive artworks. The  descriptions are both in English and French, which made it easy to learn about each piece. It was a lovely, uncrowded experience that I would recommend to anyone interested in exploring art in Paris.

Definitely a place for art lovers. Uncountable art pièces of great artists. It will take 1h30 minutes if you want to go through everything slowly and with détail. First Salle don't forget to use the tab it's amazing. Specially during rainly days it's a perfect place to spand your time in. Entry is free. There will be exposition during Novembre-January which have fees as I understood. There is no queue apart from checking the bag. it have different rooms which can be tricky not to miss anything. Places just infront of the River and from there you get a perfect view of Eiffel. There is also a restaurant/bar in the ground floor.
Spacious, clean and the atmosphere is nice Yet, to my personal opinion, the collection isn’t the best, so wouldn’t plan the rout only with a stop here  Though a nice addition to the trip!

The Musée d’Art Moderne de Paris has done an excellent job of curating and presenting the work of contemporary artists. There were plenty of English explanations of artists and their works, as well as a variety of art displayed. The permanent exhibitions are free, and there are free locker rooms within the museum for your belongings. We originally visited here after discovering the Palais de Tokyo was closed, but am very grateful that we were able to explore the works of Chirico, Modigliani, Derain, and Picasso, as well as murals by Matisse and Dufy. There are beautiful views of the Eiffel Tower on the way to the Musée d’Art Moderne de Paris from the metro.

Great museum !  Located across from the Seine. The extensive permanent collection is wonderful and it’s free. One of the best modern art collections in the world. Well worth several hours and it’s not at all crowded. The special exhibit we saw was Jean Hélion - abstract and figurative painter. Fabulous. For the special exhibits there is a charge. This one is well worth it !
The best modern art museum I've seen till date. It has several exhibitions as well.
Great museum with beautiful pieces. Free for the permanent exhibition. No line/wait times.

Excellent museum with free entry. Great murals by Raoul Dufy & Henri Matisse. I would definitely include this museum in my itinerary when I am back in Paris. Avenue de New York is close by as well for great views of the Eiffel Tower.

Very educative exhibitions. Three exhibits when I visited: the permanent, Jean Hélion and an exhibition about Arabic influence in Paris from 1900 called « Presence arabe ».  The two non permanent exhibitions are so great and so differently exposed. Both put in an amazing and fair perspective the different shapes of art.  For Jean hélion exhibition, the chronological progress makes clear his way from abstract to near realism through figurative and it really highlights the diversity of his perspectives and evolutions. I am impressed .  The « presence arabe » exhibition mixed so many painters that it is mainly a true discovery of artists and styles; though the fil rouge is the colonialism and its disaster.  I enjoyed being in this place and its extended permanent collection exhibition.
Excellent museum of modern and contemporary art, plus it’s free.

The most perfect museum experience for lovers of 20th century art. Many beautiful works by de Chirico, Modigliani, Derain, and Picasso, as well as jaw-dropping murals by Matisse and Dufy. I spent about 1.5 hours there but could have spent more — very well-worth it. It also happened to be almost empty when I went (midday on a weekday). Access to the permanent collections is free.
There are four big pictures by Don Van Vliet (Captain Beefheart) in one of the rooms. Some halls were more interesting, some much less. We visited only permanent exhibition.

I only walked past it and didn’t go inside, but the front looks very nice. The atmosphere seems great for relaxing or taking photos. The exterior would likely provide a lovely and artistic backdrop for pictures.
One of the most incredible experiences I’ve had in Paris. Had the opportunity to stand face to face with a Picasso and a Freundlich. You can’t miss this!

Amazing. You have to be an art enthusiast, otherwise you wont enjoy it fully. The guide helps, but it does so to a point. Most of the artwork is pretty abstract, consistent with the modern art. Lockers, toilettes are all part of the facilities.
The Atomic Age exposition is an excellent curation, with emotional and moving art under overarching themes.

I enjoyed visiting this museum. It was interesting and offered a code variety of modern art. The building was beautiful, the space well organized and it was really easy to access.  Entrance was free and there was no wait. The area outside is stunning (and turns into a makeshift skate park). The museum also has a lovely bookstore where you can buy art books and postcards etc.

Mercifully uncrowded museum, you can enjoy the artwork at your own pace.  I loved the pieces by Raoul Dufy and Giorgio de Chirico. A good representation of women artists too, like Natalia Gontcharova, Suzanne Valadon, Anna-Eva Bergman, Maria Helena Vieira da Silva, and Vera Pagava.  Plus it's free! Overall, a good way to spend an hour or two away from the crowds
Free, with lots of great exhibitions. Glbeaitifuo building. You are entering on one of the top floors, the exhibitions are mostly below the entrance level.  Just wish they had more works by women.

First off, it was free! Incredible as it may seem, this beautifully curated and presented collection is free! Modern art may be somewhat of a misnomer since some impressionist works are included to illustrate the progression of artists like Duffy from the early to the mid-twentieth century. Located right next to the Palais De Tokio.

This museum surprised and informed me perhaps more than any other in this beautiful City of Light. Though the Louvre offers its own splendor and the Musee d’Orsay is a treasure trove of some of my favorite impressionist artists, and while the beautiful and tranquil Marmoset Museum permits quiet and studied viewing of the works of Claude Monet, in particular, it was the Musée d’Art Moderne de Paris that awakened in me a sense of the purpose of Art, and left me questioning why other museums of modern art don’t do a better job with curating and presenting the work of contemporary artists. This museum was like a sanctuary, more than any other that I visited in the city. Its use of light and space is exceptional, propelling the viewer to one enlightened exhibit after another, and inviting one to stop and ponder the meaning of the work at hand.  All in all this is a space I would choose to visit over and over, more than any of the other art museums I have visited in the city. Second in line would be the Musée d’Orsay.

I visited the MAM for the Nicolas de Staël exhibition. This is an overlooked museum with quite a lot of interesting things to discover. While the permanent de Staël was outstanding the permanent collection is noteworthy as well. The grand Matisse hall and the rest of the 20th century classics are worth your time. Can get very busy during weekends for its current exhibitions.

This place has a few famous works by Matisse and a couple by Picasso. It is free. They need however clean up this place and fix the flooring outside as it seems to become dilapidated and embarrassing for a Paris museum of modern art.
Amazing museum containing Picasso, Matisse and other great masters. Plan on 2+ hours to dedicate to see these impressive works.  The building itself is quite impressive and used by modeling agencies.

Most visitors to Paris miss this wonderful museum. To start, from the plaza there is an incredible view of the Eiffel Tower. Enter on the opposite side of the tower view, there's rarely a wait. The three-storey mural by Raoul Dufy celebrating the history of electricity (probably 90% of visitors don't catch this theme) is wonderful. Sit down on the stools and set a spell to rake it all in. The dance murals by Matisse, that were originally intended for the Barnes House in Philadelphia are very interesting. Matisse errored in the measurements hence he create two sets of these.  The permanent collection,  now with the addition of the donation by the Josef and Anni Albers family, is strong in the 1910 to 1940 period. AND, there are always new special exhibitions - expand your horizons a bit. The museum is open, spacious and easy to navigate.

The building raised my expectations but the collection disappointed me. There are plethora of art work on display yet  few truly stand out.  Curatorship of the sections diminishes the value of the exhibited art and the intensity of the aesthetic experience.  If you are an art student or someone interested in art history, you'll still enjoy it but by the Parisian standarts this museum can't even make it to my top 10.
Huge collection of modern art , excellent presentation and worth visiting and learning about modern artists works in Paris.

In the museum there is permanent collection of paintings and statues of famous art-moderne French and world wide artists and also temporary exhibitions of modern artists like Nicholas de Staël that I was delighted to visit and see. Musée d'Art Moderne is a must see if you're in Paris.

I’ve been to Paris over a dozen times and had never heard of this museum until I googled “free things to do in Paris” this morning! What a luxury to be able to witness such a huge collection of beautiful modern art in a stunning building for free. Cloak room is free as well, staff is friendly and toilets were clean.

If you only have one day in Paris, I recommend you to come here. You can see one of the most amazing exhibitions in Paris in a quiet environment with few people. And it's free. The Eiffel Tower is very close from the magnificent terrace.Then if you have time more, you can go to Orsay or Pompidou.

Really enjoyed my time at the modern art museum. The entry is free for the permanent expositions then access to temporary expositions require a ticket. I did buy a ticket for these but still needed a good 1.5-2h to view all the permanent expositions. It's very well presented and there is great variety of styles. The museum is just across from the Alma Bridge where you can get on the Bateaux Mouches to cruise the River Seine.

What a great local resource. The museum is relatively big and has a kind of eclectic variety of works. The entrance is free for the permanent exhibitions. Always fun to explore new places and you will be surprised by the quality of pieces. If modern art is your thing, you will be happier with it.

Walk in for free. Tour the exhibit only took about 45 minutes. One or two interesting halls to keep me entertained. Can’t hurt to add this to your list, on the weekend there is a small farmers market to shop after the museum, so that made it well worth the visit.
Excellent special exhibits that are often just too packed to view calmly - best to get early morning tickets or nocturne Thursday nights - wonderful permanent collection. Interesting building.

One of my favorite museums!  I recommend this absolutely!  Discovered Charlotte Rampling’s exposition this year!  Amazing! Monsieur Bleu restaurant is great too.  The Matisse rooms are AWEsome!!!  Love the skaterboy vibe outside the museum too!
